org.fujion.plotly.layout

Class AnnotationOptions

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.fujion.ancillary.Options
      • org.fujion.plotly.layout.AnnotationOptions
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    OptionMap.IOptionMapConverter, IClientTransform

    public class AnnotationOptions
extends Options
    Layout options for annotations.

    • Field Detail

      • align

        @Option
public HorizontalAlignEnum align
        The horizontal alignment of the "text" within the box. Has an effect only if "text" spans more two or more lines (i.e. "text" contains one or more <br> HTML tags) or if an explicit width is set to override the text width.

        Default: CENTER

      • arrowcolor

        @Option
public String arrowcolor
        The color of the annotation arrow.

      • arrowhead

        @Option
public Integer arrowhead
        The end annotation arrow head style.

        Range; ≥0 and ≤8

        Default: 1

      • arrowside

        @Option
public String arrowside
        Any combination of "end", "start" joined with a "+" OR "none".

        Examples: "end", "start", "end+start", "none".

        Default: "end"

      • arrowsize

        @Option
public Double arrowsize
        The size of the end annotation arrow head, relative to "arrowwidth". A value of 1 (default) gives a head about 3x as wide as the line.

        Constraints: ≥0.3

        Default: 1

      • arrowwidth

        @Option
public Integer arrowwidth
        The width (in px) of annotation arrow line.

      • ax$number

        @Option(value="ax")
public Double ax$number
        The x component of the arrow tail about the arrow head. If "axref" is "pixel", a positive (negative) component corresponds to an arrow pointing from right to left (left to right). If "axref" is an axis, this is an absolute value on that axis, like "x", NOT a relative value.

      • ax$string

        @Option(value="ax")
public String ax$string
        The x component of the arrow tail about the arrow head as a categorical string.

      • axref

        @Option
public String axref
        Indicates in what terms the tail of the annotation (ax,ay) is specified. If "pixel", "ax" is a relative offset in pixels from "x". If set to an x axis id (e.g. "x" or "x2"), "ax" is specified in the same terms as that axis. This is useful for trendline annotations which should continue to indicate the correct trend when zoomed.

        Constraints: "pixel" | "/^x([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/"

        Default: "pixel"

      • ay$number

        @Option(value="ay")
public Double ay$number
        the y component of the arrow tail about the arrow head. If "ayref" is "pixel", a positive (negative) component corresponds to an arrow pointing from bottom to top (top to bottom). If "ayref" is an axis, this is an absolute value on that axis, like "y", NOT a relative value.

      • ay$string

        @Option(value="ay")
public String ay$string
        The y component of the arrow tail about the arrow head as a categorical string.

      • ayref

        @Option
public String ayref
        Indicates in what terms the tail of the annotation (ax,ay) is specified. If "pixel", "ay" is a relative offset in pixels from "y". If set to a y axis id (e.g. "y" or "y2"), "ay" is specified in the same terms as that axis. This is useful for trendline annotations which should continue to indicate the correct trend when zoomed.

        Constraints: "pixel" | "/^x([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/"

        Default: "pixel"

      • bgcolor

        @Option
public String bgcolor
        The background color of the annotation.

        Default: "rgba(0,0,0,0)"

      • bordercolor

        @Option
public String bordercolor
        The color of the border enclosing the annotation "text".

        Default: "rgba(0,0,0,0)"

      • borderpad

        @Option
public Integer borderpad
        The padding (in px) between the "text" and the enclosing border.

        Constraints: ≥0

        Default: 1

      • borderwidth

        @Option
public Integer borderwidth
        The width (in px) of the border enclosing the annotation "text".

        Constraints: ≥0

        Default: 1

      • captureevents

        @Option
public Boolean captureevents
        Determines whether the annotation text box captures mouse move and click events, or allows those events to pass through to data points in the plot that may be behind the annotation. By default "captureevents" is false unless "hovertext" is provided. If you use the event "plotly_clickannotation" without "hovertext" you must explicitly enable "captureevents".

      • clicktoshow

        @Option
public AnnotationOptions.ClickToShowEnum clicktoshow
        Determines how the annotation responds to clicks on the plot. If you click a data point that exactly matches the "x" and "y" values of this annotation, and it is hidden (visible: false), it will appear. In ONOFF mode, you must click the same point again to make it disappear, so if you click multiple points, you can show multiple annotations. In ONOUT mode, a click anywhere else in the plot (on another data point or not) will hide this annotation. If you need to show/hide this annotation in response to different "x" or "y" values, you can set "xclick" and/or "yclick". This is useful for example to label the side of a bar. To label markers though, "standoff" is preferred over "xclick" and "yclick".

      • font

        @Option
public final FontOptions font
        The annotation text font.

      • height

        @Option
public Integer height
        Explicit height for the text box. Taller text will be clipped.

        Constraints: ≥1

        Default: Lets the text set the box height.

      • hoverlabel

        @Option
public final HoverLabelOptions hoverlabel
        Options for the hover label.

      • hovertext

        @Option
public String hovertext
        Text to appear when hovering over this annotation. If omitted or blank, no hover label will appear.

      • opacity

        @Option
public Double opacity
        The opacity of the annotation (text + arrow).

        Constraints: 0 - 1, inclusive

        Default: 1

      • showarrow

        @Option
public Boolean showarrow
        Determines whether or not the annotation is drawn with an arrow. If true, "text" is placed near the arrow's tail. If false, "text" lines up with the "x" and "y" provided.

        Default: true

      • standoff

        @Option
public Integer standoff
        Distance, in pixels, to move the end arrowhead away from the position it is pointing at, for example to point at the edge of a marker independent of zoom. Note that this shortens the arrow from the "ax" / "ay" vector, in contrast to "xshift" / "yshift" which moves everything by this amount.

        Constraints: ≥0

        Default: 0

      • startarrowhead

        @Option
public Integer startarrowhead
        The start annotation arrow head style.

        Range; ≥0 and ≤8

        Default: 1

      • startarrowsize

        @Option
public Double startarrowsize
        The size of the start annotation arrow head, relative to "arrowwidth". A value of 1 (default) gives a head about 3x as wide as the line.

        Constraints: ≥0.3

        Default: 1

      • startstandoff

        @Option
public Integer startstandoff
        Distance, in pixels, to move the start arrowhead away from the position it is pointing at, for example to point at the edge of a marker independent of zoom. Note that this shortens the arrow from the "ax" / "ay" vector, in contrast to "xshift" / "yshift" which moves everything by this amount.

        Constraints: ≥0

        Default: 0

      • text

        @Option
public String text
        The text associated with this annotation. Plotly uses a subset of HTML tags to do things like newline (<br> ), bold (<b></b>), italics (<i></i>), hyperlinks (<a href='...'></a>). Tags <em>, <sup>, <sub> <span> are also supported.

      • textangle

        @Option
public Integer textangle
        The angle at which the "text" is drawn with respect to the horizontal.

        Default: 0

      • valign

        @Option
public VerticalAlignEnum valign
        The vertical alignment of the "text" within the box. Has an effect only if an explicit height is set to override the text height.

        Default: MIDDLE

      • visible

        @Option
public Boolean visible
        Determines whether or not the annotation is visible.

      • width

        @Option
public Integer width
        Explicit width for the text box. Wider text will be clipped. There is no automatic wrapping; use <br> to start a new line.

        Constraints: ≥1

        Default: Lets the text set the box width.

      • x$number

        @Option(value="x")
public Double x$number
        The annotation's x position as a number. If the axis "type" is "log", then you must take the log of your desired range. If the axis "type" is "date", it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis "type" is "category", it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

      • x$string

        @Option(value="x")
public String x$string
        The annotation's x position as a categorical coordinate string. If the axis "type" is "log", then you must take the log of your desired range. If the axis "type" is "date", it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis "type" is "category", it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

      • xanchor

        @Option
public HorizontalAlignEnum xanchor
        The text box's horizontal position anchor This anchor binds the "x" position to the left, center or right of the annotation. For example, if "x" is set to 1, "xref" to "paper" and "xanchor" to RIGHT, then the right-most portion of the annotation lines up with the right-most edge of the plotting area. If AUTO, the anchor is equivalent to CENTER for data-referenced annotations or if there is an arrow, whereas for paper-referenced with no arrow, the anchor picked corresponds to the closest side.

        Default: AUTO

      • xclick$number

        @Option(value="xclick")
public Double xclick$number
        Toggle the annotation when clicking a data point whose "x" value is "xclick" rather than the annotation's "x" value.

      • xclick$string

        @Option(value="xclick")
public String xclick$string
        Toggle the annotation when clicking a data point whose "x" value is "xclick" rather than the annotation's "x" value.

      • xref

        @Option
public String xref
        The annotation's x coordinate axis. If set to an x axis id (e.g. "x" or "x2"), the "x" position refers to an x coordinate If set to "paper", the "x" position refers to the distance from the left side of the plotting area in normalized coordinates where 0 (1) corresponds to the left (right) side.

        Constraints: "paper" | "/^x([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/"

      • xshift

        @Option
public Integer xshift
        Shifts the position of the whole annotation and arrow to the right (positive) or left (negative) by this many pixels.

        Default: 0

      • y$number

        @Option(value="y")
public Double y$number
        The annotation's y position as a number. If the axis "type" is "log", then you must take the log of your desired range. If the axis "type" is "date", it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis "type" is "category", it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

      • y$string

        @Option(value="y")
public String y$string
        The annotation's y position as a categorical coordinate string. If the axis "type" is "log", then you must take the log of your desired range. If the axis "type" is "date", it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis "type" is "category", it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

      • yanchor

        @Option
public VerticalAlignEnum yanchor
        The text box's vertical position anchor This anchor binds the "y" position to the top, middle or bottom of the annotation. For example, if "y" is set to 1, "yref" to "paper" and "yanchor" to TOP, then the top-most portion of the annotation lines up with the top-most edge of the plotting area. If AUTO, the anchor is equivalent to MIDDLE for data-referenced annotations or if there is an arrow, whereas for paper-referenced with no arrow, the anchor picked corresponds to the closest side.

        Default: AUTO

      • yclick$number

        @Option(value="yclick")
public Double yclick$number
        Toggle this annotation when clicking a data point whose "y" value is "yclick" rather than the annotation's "y" value.

      • yclick$string

        @Option(value="yclick")
public String yclick$string
        Toggle this annotation when clicking a data point whose "y" value is "yclick" rather than the annotation's "y" value.

      • yref

        @Option
public String yref
        The annotation's y coordinate axis. If set to an y axis id (e.g. "y" or "y2"), the "y" position refers to an y coordinate If set to "paper", the "y" position refers to the distance from the bottom of the plotting area in normalized coordinates where 0 (1) corresponds to the bottom (top).

        Constraints: "paper" | "/^y([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/"

      • yshift

        @Option
public Integer yshift
        Shifts the position of the whole annotation and arrow up (positive) or down (negative) by this many pixels.

        Default: 0
